node.title: Biden pledged $3 billion to help the world adapt to climate change. Thatâ€™s not as much as it seems.
node.alt: President Biden speaking on Tuesday during the COP26 summit in Glasgow.
node.description: The amount is half as much as what was recently proposed for a six-mile sea wall to protect Miami from the Atlantic Ocean.
node.content: ["The United States vowed at the Glasgow summit to start providing $3 billion each year, by 2024, to help developing countries adapt to climate change. The Biden administration called it \u201cthe largest U.S. commitment ever made to reduce climate impacts on those most vulnerable\u201d worldwide, assuming that Mr. Biden can persuade Congress to come up with the money.", "But how much resilience and disaster recovery does $3 billion buy? A White House official said that no one was available to talk about the pledge. So here are some recent comparison points:", "How much resilience can the world hope to get if Biden comes through on his $3 billion pledge? It might be enough to protect a smaller version of Miami. The Corps of Engineers recently proposed spending $6 billion for a six-mile long, 20-foot-high sea wall to protect Miami from the Atlantic Ocean. (Locals hated the idea, saying it would ruin the view.)", "\u201cAny amount of money invested is moving in the right direction,\u201d Ed Johnson, former chief financial officer at FEMA and now head of EHJ-Solutions, a consulting group, said of Mr. Biden\u2019s pledge. \u201cBut this should be considered nothing more than a small down payment.\u201d"]
